title: The Attorney representing Persolve LLC lied, besides clearly contradicting himself. The court allowed it, he won?
question: I have a letter showing I contracted a debt relief agency on September 10, 2010 and I never used the credit card after that, I cut it up. They made things up. I survived a pulmonary saddle embolism and had to go to court during that trying time. Can I file a lawsuit against them it has physically affected me. The judge, on paper, referred to me as the plaintiff and then wrote judgment for Plaintiff, meaning Persolve...
answers:
It seems like you represented yourself at trial and lost. Because you represented yourself, you probably didn't make the objections that you needed to make in order to keep the false/inaccurate facts from coming into evidence. If your intent was to show that the debt was time-barred, you may have failed to prove that with sufficient evidence. So for purposes of the debt collection case, the facts that you believe are false were accepted as true. Once the trial is over and the judgment entered, it's unlikely that you could reverse the judgment on appeal, even with an attorney to help you.

However, it might also be true that Persolve made statements that were false, or took other actions (before or during the case) that were misleading and unfair. If you can prove that Persolve violated the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA), then the emotional and physical symptoms that were caused by their actions could be part of the damages.

You should identify an attorney that handles FDCPA cases, and ask for a consultation. There are a number of established firms in Southern California that specialize in this type of litigation.

A proper review of your case and your situation requires a review of all of the relevant documents and the entire case file. As far as the case that you lost, did you plead, and then prove, as an affirmative defense that the Statute of Limitations had run before the lawsuit was filed against you? As far as the "debt relief agency" is concerned, did it communicate with the creditor and make a promise that you would make a payment? If so, that might extend the SOL. If you want a good evaluation, you need to meet with a lawyer and have the lawyer review all of the documents and the facts.

I assure you lawsuits are just as stressful when you file them as when someone else does. And there is no suing for emotional distress from a lawsuit.

Bankruptcy might be worth it though.
